intro: Trophaeum chrysanthum, commonly known as the golden bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its striking yellow-orange petals that resemble bells, which bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and has narrow, lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sunlight, making it a popular choice for rock gardens. Due to its ornamental value, it is often cultivated in gardens and botanical collections.
